sentences.sentence: Since euthanasia and assisted suicide were legalized in 2016, more than 30,000 Canadians have died these ways.
Many of these deaths were of the sort the law's proponents envisioned.

But many others raise grave concerns about how the law is currently working: shackled prisoners have been euthanized; death has been offered(https://www.cbc.ca/news/politics/veterans-maid-rcmp-investigation-1.6663885) to veterans with PTSD; and there have been alarming reports(https://www.ctvnews.ca/health/woman-with-chemical-sensitivities-chose-medically-assisted-death-after-failed-bid-to-get-better-housing-1.5860579) of requests for euthanasia due to lack of housing(https://financialpost.com/tag/housing-market/) for persons with disabilities.

It seems many Canadians are being offered or are requesting death because of a lack of support in living their lives.But, say University of Toronto philosophers Kayla Wiebe and Amy Mullin in a recent paper(https://jme.bmj.com/content/early/2023/04/25/jme-2022-108871.abstract), even if admittedly "unjust conditions" influence the request for death, or are even its principal motivation, death should still be on offer.

The need to prioritize autonomy apparently means that, even when there is an "unjust lack of choices available to people," any resulting "choices" to die must be provided for.It is a sad commentary on this country that people facing great personal difficulties are unable to get the help that would allow them to continue living their lives.

And that's not just on politicians and bureaucrats, it's on all of us: society should be supporting those in distress, not just government.One disturbing case involved Christine Gauthier, retired corporal and Paralympian, who had been seeking help for over five years to get a wheelchair ramp installed.

Gauthier shared(https://www.ctvnews.ca/politics/paralympian-trying-to-get-wheelchair-ramp-says-veterans-affairs-employee-offered-her-assisted-dying-1.6179325) with CTV her disbelief when the government couldn't accommodate her request but instead offered her euthanasia: "You're going to be helping me to die but you won't help me to live?

"Disability advocates, including the UN Special Rapporteur on the rights of persons with disabilities(https://www.ohchr.org/en/statements/2019/04/end-mission-statement-united-nations-special-rapporteur-rights-persons), have emphasized(https://thewalrus.ca/assisted-dying/ ) how euthanasia and assisted suicide, and especially their availability for those who are not terminally ill, reinforces ableist assumptions that disabled lives are not worth living.The euthanizing of prisoners is tragically ironic.
The death penalty was abolished in Canada because of fear of wrongful conviction and concern that the state should not be in the business of killing.
But this cautious approach to ending human life seems to have been overturned.

In the 21st century prisoners get lethal injections in the same manner as they did under capital punishment, i.e., shackled and surrounded by guards, but now it is done out of respect for their right to autonomy.As a society, we have thrown caution to the wind in the speedy expansion of euthanasia and assisted suicide, both in terms of the considerable numbers of Canadians being euthanized and in the rapidly evolving rules about who is eligible.
In 2021, the courts removed the requirement that death be reasonably foreseeable.
This year access to voluntary death was due to become available to those with mental illness, although this has now been delayed by a year.
Expanding eligibility to children is also under discussion.The common good needs to be front and centre in conversations about euthanasia and assisted suicide in Canada.
Early in the pandemic, Canadians and their governments prioritized protection of the most vulnerable people in the community.
That was in marked contrast to how advocates and the courts were approaching euthanasia and assisted suicide.
Concern for community has now given way to radical personal autonomy - amid reports that even the very liberal established limits and safeguards are failing.You like Ottawa's industrial policies?
What about government failure?

(https://financialpost.com/opinion/advocates-industrial-policy-should-worry-about-government-failure)Opinion: Postmedia book is an ideological smear job(https://financialpost.com/opinion/postmedia-book-ideological-smear-job)More public spending means less inflation?
Really?

(https://financialpost.com/opinion/more-public-spending-means-less-inflation-really)Whatever shortcomings there were in government and social responses to the spread of COVID-19(https://financialpost.com/tag/covid-19/), and there obviously were many, we did see beautiful expressions of interconnectedness and responsibility for our families and communities amidst life and death issues.
We need to recover that sense when thinking about euthanasia and assisted suicide.
Canadians need the means to live well, rather than merely the means to be killed.

We don't want it to become a "Canadian value" that if you are having trouble, your government stands ready to assist you out of your life and into whatever comes next.Rebecca Vachon is health program director at the Cardus think-tank.
